--- title: "Introduction to RStudio" subtitle: "Day 1 - Introduction to Data Analysis with R" author: "Selina Baldauf" institute: "Freie Universit√§t Berlin - Theoretical Ecology" date: today date-format: long format: revealjs: footer: "Selina Baldauf // Introduction RStudio" highlight-style: breeze mainfont: Cabinet Grotesk slide-number: true show-slide-number: all incremental: false self-contained: true code-line-numbers: false auto-stretch: false scrollable: true fig-align: center theme: slides.scss execute: echo: true warning: false message: false from: markdown+emoji title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: img/Rstudio_logo.png data-background-position: 90% 85% data-background-size: "20%" --- ## Difference between R and RStudio . . . :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} ![](img/Rlogo.png){fig-align="center" width=15% }
R is the **programming language** and the **program** that does the actual work - Can be used with many different programming environments (But RStudio is the best for R) ::: :::{.column width="50%"} :::{.fragment} ![](img/Rstudio_logo.png){fig-align="center" width=12%}
RStudio is the **integrated development environment** (IDE) - Provides an interface to R - Specifically built around R code - Execute code - Syntax highlighting - File and project management - ... ::: ::: ::: ## Difference between R and RStudio :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} ![](img/Rlogo.png){width=15% }
R is the **programming language** and the **program** that does the actual work ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ![](img/Rstudio_logo.png){width=12%}
RStudio is the **integrated development environment** (IDE) ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note} ## Summary You can use R without RStudio but RStudio without R would be of little use ::: ## Difference between R and RStudio :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} **R** is like the engine ::: :::{.column width="50%"} **RStudio** is more like the dashboard, etc. ::: ::: ![Analogy and image from [ModernDive Book](https://moderndive.com/1-getting-started.html#r-rstudio)](img/day1/car_engine.png) ## Basic idea of writing code for data analysis ::: {.incremental} - Break down your process into small steps - Write precise instructions telling the computer what to do in each step - For this you can use the programming language R - Tell R to execute these instructions - R will return the result of your instructions (or an error message) - You can do all of this inside RStudio ::: ## A quick tour around RStudio ![](img/day1/RStudio_all.png){fig-align="center" width=85%} ## Console pane{.nonincremtal} :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} - Execute R code - Output from R code in scripts is printed there - Type a command into the console and execute with `Enter/Return` ::: {.callout-tip} Use arrow keys to bring back last commands ::: ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ![](img/day1/RStudio_console.png) ::: ::: ## Script pane :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} - Write scripts with R code - Scripts are text files with R commands (file ending `.R`) - Use scripts to save commands for reuse ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ![](img/day1/RStudio_script.png) ::: ::: ## Script pane :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} - Create a new R script:
**File -> New File -> R Script** - Save an R script:
**File->Save (Ctrl/Cmd + S)** - Run code line by line with **Run button (Ctrl+Enter/Cmd+Return)** - You can open multiple scripts ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ![](img/day1/RStudio_script.png) ::: ::: ::: {.callout-note} ## Summary Use **scripts** for all your analysis and for commands that you want to save.
Use **console** for temporary commands, e.g. to test something. ::: ## Environment pane :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} - Shows objects currently present in the R session - Is empty if you start R ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ![](img/day1/RStudio_environment.png) ::: ::: ## Files pane :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} - Similar to Explorer/Finder - Browse project structure and files - Find and open files - Create new folders - Delete files - Rename files - ... - Practical if you don't want to switch between File Explorer and RStudio all the time ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ![](img/day1/RStudio_Files.png) ::: ::: ## Plot pane {.nonincremental} :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} - Plots that are created with R will be shown here ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ![](img/day1/RStudio_plot.png) ::: ::: ## Project oriented workflow :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} - One directory with all files relevant for project - Scripts, data, plots, documents, ... ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ```md Project | |- data | |- documents | | | |- notes | | | |- reports | |- analysis | | | |- clean_data.R | | | |- statistics.R | | ``` [Example project structure]{.text-small} ::: ::: ## Project oriented workflow :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} - One directory with all files relevant for project - Scripts, data, plots, documents, ... - An RStudio project is just a normal directory with an **.Rproj** file ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ```md Project | |- data | |- documents | | | |- notes | | | |- reports | |- analysis | | | |- clean_data.R | | | |- statistics.R | |- *.RProj ``` [Example R Studio project structure]{.text-small} ::: ::: ## Project oriented workflow :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} **Advantages** of using RStudio projects ::: {.incremental} - Easy to navigate in R Studio (**File pane**) - Easy to find and access scripts and data in RStudio - Project root is working directory - Open multiple projects simultaneously in separate RStudio instances ::: ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ```md Project | |- data | |- documents | | | |- notes | | | |- reports | |- analysis | | | |- clean_data.R | | | |- statistics.R | |- *.RProj ``` [Example R Studio project structure]{.text-small} ::: ::: ## Create an RStudio project {.nonincremental} :::{.columns} :::{.column width="50%"} Create a project from scratch: 1. **File -> New Project -> New Directory -> New Project** 2. Enter a directory name (this will be the name of your project) 3. Choose the Directory where the project should be initiated 4. **Create Project** ::: :::{.column width="50%"} ![](img/day1/RStudio_Files.png) [Example project structure in RStudio]{.text-small} ::: ::: RStudio will now create and open the project for you. ## Navigate an RStudio project ![](img/day1/RStudio_Files_navig.png){fig-align="center"} ## Open a project from outside RStudio To open an RStudio project from your file explorer/finder, just double click on the **.Rproj** file ![](img/day1/open_project.png){fig-align=center} ## Open a project inside RStudio To open an RStudio project from RStudio, click on the project symbol on the top right of R Studio and select the project from the list. ![](img/day1/open_project_rstudio.png){fig-align="center" width=45%} # Now you {.inverse} [Task 1 (25 min)]{.highlight-blue}
